newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish church begs lawmakers not to ease abortion.
newsitem.headline: Polish church begs lawmakers not to ease abortion.

text.p: Poland's Roman Catholic Church, which says its ties with the state have plunged to the lowest point in years, pleaded with parliament on Tuesday not to pass a bill liberalising the country's current anti-abortion law.
The bishops, ending an annual plenary conference, wrote to the lower house speaker asking deputies not to overturn a Senate veto on the bill when they vote on the issue this week.
"We understand that you face a decision which -- for various reasons -- is hard for you. But we appeal to you: Stand in defence of life," said the letter quoted by PAP news agency.
The Senate blocked the bill early this month and its lower house backers must muster a majority of 50 percent plus one vote to pass the measure, which they first approved in August.
The vote could be close, as members of the SLD's smaller Peasant party coalition partner may opt against the bill.
The measure would allow women to end pregnancies before the 12th week, if they cannot afford to raise a child or have other personal problems, but only after counselling and reflection.
Abortions are currently allowed only if a pregnancy threatens a woman's life or health, results from rape or incest, or when the foetus is irreparably damaged.

The reform's backers, including the ruling, ex-communist Democratic Left Alliance (SLD), say the bill, which also provides for sex education in schools and cheaper contraception, will prevent much misery.
They argue that abortion tourism in neighbouring states is anyway easily available to women with money.
But the church, backed by the full authority of Polish-born Pope John Paul, has desperately fought what it sees as a licence to kill unborn children.
The issue is one of several deeply straining relations between the church and the ruling, secular-minded left, led by politicians who were part of the pre-1989 communist system.
On Monday the Episcopate's Secretary-General, Bishop Tadeusz Pieronek, said that these relations had never been so bad since 1993, when the ex-communists won parliamentary polls.
"All threads of agreement have been snapped," he said.

Apart from the abortion issue, the church and SLD have clashed over parliament's delays in ratifying a concordat treaty with the Vatican which was concluded by a previous, pro-Catholic government just before the 1993 elections.
The church also wants Poland's new constitution now being drafted to invoke God, an idea rejected by much of the SLD.
Such issues may become a significant theme in parliamentary elections due in September next year, especially as 90 percent of Poles are at least nominally Catholics.
An alliance of right-wing parties grouped around the militantly pro-church Solidarity is running neck and neck with the SLD in opinion polls.

Ex-communist President Aleksander Kwasniewski and the party's prime minister Wlodzimierz Cimoszewicz on Tuesday both urged the Church to be open to greater compromise on issues dividing Polish society.
